News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: As Brandenburg and Saxony head to the polls in elections on Sunday, all eyes will be on how the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party performs in the eastern states.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: "It is possible these two results shake up the political system nationwide," Olaf Boehnke, Berlin Director & Senior Advisor at Rasmussen Global, told Euronews.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Here's why.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: If for the first time in German history, AfD wins in state elections, it will send shockwaves to Berlin where the so-called "grand coalition" between Angela Merkel’s Christian Democrats (CDU/CSU) and the centre-left Social Democrats (SPD) is already on shaky ground.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Saxony, home to four million inhabitants where 3.3 million are entitled to vote, less than a year ago saw the worst far-right riots in Germany for decades. They were triggered by the murder of 35-year-old resident Daniel Hillig.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Read more: German court convicts Syrian over the stabbing that triggered Chemnitz riots

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: In Brandenburg, the state surrounding Berlin where two million of its citizens are eligible to vote on Sunday, the AfD has made waves over its use of campaign posters.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: One of the party's slogans for these state elections is "Wende 2.0". Wende ("turnaround" in German) refers to the collapse of East German communism when the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 and the country was reunified a year later.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Many have slammed the party for allegedly appropriating German history for their own gain.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Read more: German far-right invokes 1989 spirit to woo voters in the east

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: The AfD has done in Germany "what all populists across Europe have been doing successfully, including Trump and Farage," according to Boehnke.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: "While the moderate and left try to sell hope, populists deal in fear," he said.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Boehnke said there is a cross-section of German society who are not the typical poor, working-class but with a good income, who "reached a point a couple of years ago where they didn't believe in the political system as it is anymore".

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: The AfD benefitted from this mood, which is particularly strong in eastern Germany, by saying: "You are losers, everyone betrayed you, now they are letting migrants into the country but we will give you the good old days back," he added.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: In the formerly communist eastern states, three decades after the country's reunification, many voters still feel left behind and disadvantaged compared to the West, he cited as the catalyst for this feeling.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Boehnke said social media played a huge role in the AfD gaining more support when it became more popular because many of these "people stopped believing in the objectivity of news".

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: "They stopped reading public news and rely on social media, like YouTube or Facebook, as their only sources of information," he said.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: "The algorithms of these social platforms, as we know, work as such that the more you read specific news content, the more they offer you from this the more they offer you from this kind of source."

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: In many East German cities and communities, AfD politicians are prevalent in local politics and in many cases, they are figures who enjoy local prestige.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: The party has concentrated on being in touch with people "on the ground," according to Boehnke, which means in some smaller villages and towns in the East, AfD posters are the only ones that have been put up.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Brandenburg is governed by a so-called red-red coalition consisting of the SPD, whose politician Dietmar Woidke has been prime minister since 2013, and the radical Left Party.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: In the 2014 state elections, the SPD performed best gaining 31.9% of the vote, followed by the CDU with 23%, the Left with 18.6%, the AfD with 12.2% and the Greens with 6.2%. Voter turnout in 2014 was only 47.9%.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Saxony has a grand coalition of CDU and SPD, lead by CDU politician Michael Kretschmer who took charge in 2017 after the previous prime minister Stanislaw Tillich resigned when the AfD won more votes than the CDU in the federal elections.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: In the 2014 state elections, the CDU garnered 39.4% of votes, the Left won the second-most seats with 18.9%, ahead of the SPD’s 12.4%, followed by the AfD with 9.7%, and the Greens with 5.7%.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Just days from election day, the SPD and AfD are neck and neck in Brandenburg, according to pollsters.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Losing the state, which the SPD has run since German reunification in 1990, would intensify calls within the party for it to quit Merkel’s coalition and to rebuild in opposition following a nationwide slump in its support to below 15%.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: It is expected that the SPD and Left Party may start talks with the Greens to form a red-red-green coalition after the election.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: In Saxony, the CDU is still ahead despite a drop in the polls and has caught up with the AfD in recent weeks.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: Since the fall of communism, the state has been ruled by CDU prime ministers, so has been considered the "home" of Christian Democrats.

News_name: Why are this weekend's state elections in Germany so significant?
News_News_text_name: However, the party's coalition partners, the SPD, have fallen further and further behind the Left and Greens in recent polls.

News_News_text_name: Resistance to antibiotics is growing and could pose a greater threat to human survival than climate change, Britain's chief medical officer has warned.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: Dame Sally Davies says at least ten million people worldwide could die every year if antibiotic use is not decreased.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: The discovery of penicillin in the 1940s signalled the dawn of the antibiotic era and revolutionised therapeutic medicine forever.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: Antibiotics are compounds capable of fighting bacterial infections. Yet dangerous bacteria are becoming increasingly resistant to them.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: Antibiotic consumption in the past 20 years has increased dramatically, with the NHS reporting a rise of 65% in 76 countries across the world between 2000 to 2015.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: Overuse of antibiotics has serious consequences leading to an era where they do not work to fight disease anymore.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: Davies says antibiotic resistance is the biggest threat.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: "Like climate change, we humans are doing it to ourselves, but it could kill us before climate change does. It is a very important area. And we are underinvesting in sorting it out. It seems that humanity is not very good at sorting out a problem that's growing very slowly."

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: She added: "At least ten million could die every year if we don't get on top of this. And that is more than die at the moment of cancer and diabetes. So this would be a serious issue."

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: She also expresses concern that potential post-Brexit deals with countries like the United States could allow very high levels of antibiotics to enter the food chain.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: "We should not be importing beef or other animals where antibiotics have been misused. And growth promotion is a misuse in my book because it leads to problems across the world," Davies says.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: The use of growth hormones in US beef has led to an EU ban on its import by member states.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'
News_News_text_name: Strict EU regulations on farming have led to a significant decrease in antibiotic use by the UK animal sector, including a dramatic drop in antibiotic use in chickens.

News_name: 'Antibiotic resistance could kill us before climate change'

News_News_text_name: Euronews spoke to two opera singers who have worked with Domingo as well as an opera student who has experience in the industry — their names have been changed due to their wish to remain anonymous.

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: Emily said she hasn't had a negative experience with either Domingo or any other colleagues.

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: "Some may have different barriers to you, but in general, they are all very respectful and professional. Remember, we are used to a lot more physical contact in this industry than in other professions."

News_News_text_name: Someone has to hold your hand, your arm or put their arms around you — these situations are commonplace, but in other jobs, they are not," she explained.

News_News_text_name: "Many in positions of power are bad-tempered, and the way that they react when they are rejected is questionable," she said. "A director once told us that you can refuse nude scenes, but it does not go down well."

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: "Unfortunately, there are too many soloists and no union for them, and I think there are many who do not dare to speak out," she said.

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: The reason? Many have no contract, working as freelancers they rely on the favour of agents and directors.

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: "It's a tricky business," said Emily. She believes that in the opera industry it is even harder than other similar industries because roles are clearly gendered. "You cannot give a man's role to a woman or vice versa," she explained.

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: "I do not think our industry is different, there are people like this everywhere (who use their positions of power to exploit others). I'm glad that women are coming forward, that they want to be heard and seen and I'm sure this is something (sexual harassment) that still exists but I have no experience with it," explained Emily.

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: "I think he is a very straightforward person," said Emily. "If it turns out that there is overwhelming evidence to support the allegations, it's a real shame."

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: "He has been an important part of the opera world for many, many years, and is much respected and loved by many, and I think the opera world is saddened to see these allegations have been made."

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: "Until there has been a proper trial, he should be able to continue his career and his life," she added. "It's unfair to throw him in front of a bus just because someone says something that has not been properly investigated."

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: "It is really harmful to him and his career, and I support the European houses that support him."

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: Emily still considers discussions about sexual harassment in the opera industry to be meaningful and necessary, adding that they will help to change the environment for the better.

News_name: Opera singers on sexual assault allegations facing Placido Domingo
News_News_text_name: For Sarah, the debate also shows the imbalance in gender distribution among directors in the opera world. She hopes this will change in the future by opening up dialogue on the matter.

Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: Homes and interiors tell a story — both politically and culturally — of a whole country, according to Isabelle Bonnet, the curator of ‘Home Sweet Home’ photography exhibition.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: The showcase presents a complex image of the British home, carefully documented by photographers from the sixties to the present day.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: It is part of the Rencontres d’Arles photography festival in southern France, which is celebrating its 50th year.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: A new photography style that emerged in the sixties turned some photographers away from the streets and into the domestic space, documenting British homes instead, an important component of a nation's identity and political history.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: At the same time, ‘what could highlight British photography better than the theme of home: so dear to the heart of British people?’ says Bonnet.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: She walked Euronews through the exhibition, highlighting its most striking stories.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: The exhibition is divided into chapters and the first one is about everyday life. The things that we probably wouldn’t notice in the daily routine if the photographers didn’t point them out to us, the curator explains.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: The chapter ‘After Windrush, a multicultural society’ tells the story of Empire Windrush cruise ship passengers who came to the UK from the Caribbean to take part in post-war reconstruction hoping for a brighter future. Perfect homes and photographs were very important for them - to convince the family back home that things were going well. For many, dealing with racism was an everyday reality.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: Photographs of family homes during the Thatcher era immediately catch the eye, with their striking realism and Anthony Haughey’s impressive work with colour and light. He lived with one of the featured families for a year, capturing their everyday life and offering a window into how things were for the whole generation.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: Edmund Clark has explored the so-called ‘Control order houses’ - the domestic spaces-turned- confinement. According to an anti-terrorism bill passed in 2005, the Home Office was allowed to restrict the civil liberties of individuals on the grounds of “reasonable suspicion”. A person under such suspicion could be separated from their home and family to be put under house arrest in a secret location.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: The exhibition also gives a chance to look through the windows of some of the multi-storey council housing that was demolished due to the low-quality of its construction.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: The Belgravia series by Karen Knorr in 1979-1981 offers a rare insight into the home of the elite, not only documenting their lifestyle in pictures but also eavesdropping on their conversations. Quotes including “There is nothing wrong with Privilege as long as you are ready to pay for it” or “You couldn’t get me to eat lentils even if you paid me £1 per lentil,” were captured from the owners of the flats in Belgravia, a wealthy district in central London.

News_name: Photographs of British homes tell stories of the generations
News_News_text_name: The exhibition is open until the end of September.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: This article is updated regularly as events unfold.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The United Kingdom is due to leave the European Union — an economic and political partnership of 28 countries — bringing to an end 46 years of British membership.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Brexit is set to be the most important constitutional shake-up the UK has known since it joined the six-nation European Economic Community in 1973, and represents the first time the European institution has lost a member.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The process has plunged the UK into its worst political and constitutional crisis since the Second World War. The country had been due to leave the EU on March 29, 2019, but the revised departure date is now October 31 after gridlock in parliament twice forced the government to seek an extension.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The delay forced the resignation of Prime Minister Theresa May, now replaced by Boris Johnson. His stance in the early days of his premiership has led many to believe that a withdrawal deal with the EU may be all but impossible to achieve, raising the prospect of a disruptive UK departure with no agreement in place.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The UK voted to leave the EU by 52% to 48% in a June 2016 referendum. The result has increased strains between the UK's individual countries: England (53%) and Wales (52.5%) voted to leave, whereas Scotland and Northern Ireland voted by 62% and 56% respectively to remain in the EU.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Described as largely an English nationalist project — although factors such as austerity and frustration with traditional politics undoubtedly came into play — Brexit plays into a wider debate concerning the role of the nation state in an age of globalisation. Many are concerned that it has shifted attention from major global challenges, not least the battle to contain climate change.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: For many in Europe, the prospect of an institutionalised rift between the UK and the EU weakens the continent at a time when the likes of America, China and Russia are becoming increasingly assertive.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The new British prime minister has sparked fury among opponents of a no-deal Brexit by announcing plans to suspend parliament for five weeks in September and October, reducing the time available for lawmakers (MPs) to try to block such a scenario. Several legal challenges to the move have been launched.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The former foreign secretary and London mayor took over the reins after winning the Conservative Party leadership contest. He signalled immediately a reinvigorated drive to take the UK out of the EU on October 31, "no ifs or buts", and appointing prominent Brexiteers to key posts in his new cabinet.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Johnson took some by surprise with a demand for the Irish backstop to be removed from the negotiated withdrawal deal that had been repeatedly rejected by the UK parliament — a demand that was quickly rebuffed by the EU. The prime minister followed up with a formal plea in August.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: He has since visited Berlin and Paris, where the German and French leaders threw down the gauntlet to the prime minister, suggesting he could find an alternative solution within a month. UK and EU negotiators are to meet twice a week in September.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The backstop is essentially an insurance policy to avoid a hard border — such as border posts — between Northern Ireland (part of the UK) and the Republic of Ireland (part of the EU), post-Brexit. In the absence of a free trade deal it would keep the UK close — and Northern Ireland even closer — to the EU.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The withdrawal deal was negotiated by London and Brussels over an 18-month period and approved by the 27 other EU governments in November 2018 — before being rejected three times by the British parliament.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: European leaders in the EU's institutions and in national governments continue to insist the deal cannot be reopened. At their June summit — preoccupied with other priorities including renewing the EU's top posts — they once again ruled out a renegotiation of the withdrawal agreement. The message has since been repeated by outgoing European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, echoing similar warnings by several other national leaders.

News_News_text_name: Despite the prime minister's optimistic message that a new agreement can be struck with the EU — although since his assertion that the odds on a no-deal Brexit were a "million to one", he has since said it's "touch and go" — both sides have become entrenched in their positions amid an intensifying blame game.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In late July a senior UK minister stated that the government was working on the assumption that the European Union would not renegotiate its Brexit deal. There are plans to ramp up no-deal preparations, with more funds promised.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The EU27 countries have been united in holding firm on the withdrawal agreement, which some feel is already generous to the UK. But although they refuse to rewrite the terms of the UK’s exit — including the Irish border guarantee — EU leaders are more open to modifying an agreed framework for future ties. German Chancellor Angela Merkel has repeated her call for a deal leading to a "close partnership" between the UK and EU countries.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The two sides' positions appear hard to reconcile. The UK wants to keep many benefits from the existing arrangements but is intent on leaving the EU's single market and customs union — and taking control of its money, borders and laws. The EU's priority is to preserve the integrity of its single market, institutions and founding principles.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Running parallel to the Brexit saga has been the UK's evolving relationship with the United States, with which Britain hopes to strike a future trade deal. Boris Johnson met President Donald Trump at a G7 summit and admitted talks would be tough. Trade experts say the UK faces a key choice over regulatory alignment: whether to stay close to EU rules to access the European market, or follow American regulation.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: If his attempt at renegotiation fails, Boris Johnson has repeatedly said he is determined to take the UK out of the EU without a deal this autumn — a stance which won him strong support among party's members, but which many say would be disastrous.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: However, the government has only a slim majority in parliament — cut to one after a by-election defeat to the Liberal Democrats — and many MPs, even among the ruling Conservatives, vehemently oppose a "no-deal" Brexit and have vowed to block it.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: All eyes are on parliament's return on September 3. Opposition parties are expected to try to pass a law to try to prevent the government from taking the country out of the EU without a deal, forcing it to seek a further Brexit delay. European leaders would need to approve unanimously an extension to the UK's membership.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: But time is tight, and no-deal opponents have a mountain to climb to pass legislation. Whether they can stop a no-deal Brexit from happening has become even more uncertain, given Johnson's plan to prorogue parliament from mid-September.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: This came despite MPs having earlier approved a move to make it more difficult for the government to do so. But Johnson and his supporters — who deny the prorogation is for political reasons — argue a new session of parliament is needed for a new government agenda.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn also intends to bring a no-confidence vote, initially proposing to head a temporary government in order to delay Brexit and call a general election. However, there was hostility to his leadership among other opposition parties. It's thought some pro-EU Tory MPs may be prepared to move to bring down their own government as a last resort.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The opposition to a no-deal exit and the government's fragile majority have increased expectations that an election will be held in the autumn. Some believe that this is a scenario that Johnson and his team are actively seeking — and that they may look to delay a public vote until after the UK has already left the EU.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The key dates ahead:

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In the absence of an alternative agreement, the default legal position is that the UK will leave the EU on the revised scheduled departure date of October 31.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Without a formal exit deal, legal arrangements covering many aspects of everyday life — including the rights of British and European citizens — would abruptly cease to apply. It would also bring an immediate change in the trading relationship between the UK and the EU.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Although some believe the fallout would quickly force both sides back to the negotiating table, relations would be further damaged — especially if the UK refused to pay its "divorce bill", as Boris Johnson has threatened to do.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: A "no-deal" Brexit would hit the UK's economy but also those of its closest neighbours on the continent — and particularly the island of Ireland, where the survival of a hard-fought peace accord is at stake after decades of political violence.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Many political leaders, institutions, companies and individuals have warned of severe disruption and economic damage on both sides of the English Channel — with the UK being hit worse than the EU.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: However, Brexiteers have long dismissed “Project Fear” forecasts and some argue that the UK could survive perfectly well under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The heightened uncertainty amid a winter of British political turmoil forced the UK and the EU, as well as people and businesses on both sides of the English Channel, to step up no-deal preparations ahead of the original March deadline. Such plans are now being revived in the run-up to October.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In March the European Commission said it had completed its no-deal preparations, having released its Contingency Action Plan for Brexit in December. In a no-deal scenario, it confirms that the rights of EU citizens living in the UK and Britons on the continent would no longer be protected at European level — and lays out basic plans to regulate financial services, air transport, road haulage, customs and exports, and climate policy.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Theresa May's government published a series of papers — some updated under her successor — advising UK citizens and businesses on the consequences and how to prepare for no-deal. It said the EU would treat the UK as a "third country", and there would be no agreement on applying arrangements set out in the exit deal.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: British economic sectors reliant on close, smooth arrangements with Europe have warned of the dangers of new costs and restrictions being imposed overnight. Among those sounding alarm bells are manufacturing industries — including the car industry, food and drink, chemicals and pharmaceuticals – as well as the health service, tourism, and financial services. There have also been warnings over farming and fishing — despite strong support for Brexit from within these two sectors.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: As the process dragged on without formal approval for an exit deal from the UK and EU parliaments, the focus shifted even more sharply to “no deal” preparations.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In August 2019, after the Bank of England lowered its growth forecast for the UK post-Brexit, its governor Mark Carney warned that in the event of no deal the economy would suffer an instant hit, prices would rise and the pound would fall, and even large profitable industries would become "uneconomic".

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Government documents leaked to a Sunday newspaper, based on the government's preparations for a no-deal Brexit and codenamed "Operation Yellowhammer", contained warnings of possible food, medicine and fuel shortages.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In April a leaked letter by the government's most senior civil servant warned of an economic recession, food price rises, a severe impact on Britain's security services, police forces and legal system, and a return to direct rule by the UK government in Northern Ireland. In early August a leaked government document contained similar warnings.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In June, the same civil servant, Sir Mark Sedwill, said government and public services were in "pretty good shape" to cope with a no-deal Brexit at the end of October. He added that in the private sector the level of preparedness varied from sector to sector.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In November 2018, two major reports by the UK Treasury and the Bank of England assessed the potential damage to the British economy of various Brexit scenarios.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In its assessment of EU preparations for no-deal, the UK House of Commons Library describes the Commission's programme as one of "damage limitation" to protect the EU27 countries.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Johnson's appointment follows a prolonged period of turmoil in British politics. This came to a head when Theresa May — who failed to get her EU divorce deal through parliament — became the latest in a long line of Conservative prime ministers to be brought down by Europe.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In the wake of the repeated parliamentary defeats for the EU divorce deal, the House of Commons twice forced the British government to seek to delay Brexit. EU national leaders met for a special European Council summit on April 10 and agreed to a six-month "flexible extension" to the UK's departure from the bloc, with a new exit date set for October 31. The country can leave earlier if its parliament approves the negotiated withdrawal deal.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: But the extension of the UK's EU membership forced the country to take part in the European Parliament elections in May — and send 73 newly-elected MEPs to Strasbourg in July.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Nigel Farage's new Brexit Party, which advocates leaving the EU without a formal agreement, came top of the European vote. But there was a strong showing from pro-EU parties, in particular, the Liberal Democrats, who want to reverse Brexit altogether.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Britain's two main parties — the Conservatives and the Labour opposition — were severely punished by voters. Many Conservatives are furious at the failure to “deliver Brexit”, while Labour has been accused of sitting on the fence.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The results indicated that opinion in the UK is becoming still more polarised over Brexit, confirming the results of surveys which suggest that people have become increasingly entrenched in two camps — those who wish to remain in the EU, and those who are determined to leave, even with no deal.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In November 2018 the British government and EU leaders approved a deal on the terms of the separation — the Withdrawal Agreement — and a Political Declaration on the nature of future EU-UK ties.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Despite its triple rejection by the UK parliament, the EU insists the Withdrawal Agreement is the only one on offer and cannot be altered. It is ready, however, to modify the Political Declaration. A successfully ratified deal would pave the way for an orderly UK exit from the European Union, quickly followed by full trade talks between the two sides.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The near 600-page Withdrawal Agreement would be legally binding and settles the key “divorce” issues: the UK’s financial obligations to the EU, citizens' rights — those of EU citizens living in the UK and Britons living on the continent — and arrangements for the Irish border. Set to become the only land frontier between the UK and the EU, both sides agree this must remain open, but the historically sensitive and complex issue bedevilled the talks.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: A ratified exit deal would also pave the way for a the way for a planned transition period to come into effect after the UK’s departure. During this period many existing arrangements would remain in place, allowing for more time to sort out future EU-UK relations and avoid an abrupt “cliff-edge” exit.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: If no UK-EU trade deal was agreed by the end of December 2020 — although an extension to this period is possible under the draft accord — a "backstop" mechanism would come into force to keep the Irish border open. This would set up a basic UK-wide customs union with the EU, but with Northern Ireland more deeply integrated with the bloc's rules.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The Political Declaration accompanying the Withdrawal Agreement is much shorter and covers future relations. The 26-page document is not legally binding — but could form the basis for a trade agreement to be negotiated after Brexit.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Unlike Conservative Eurosceptics and Northern Irish unionists who have focused their hostility on the backstop arrangements in the Withdrawal Agreement, the UK's Labour Party has emphasised its opposition to the Political Declaration. Leader Jeremy Corbyn has argued that the document is too vague and would lead the UK into a "blindfold Brexit".

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Michel Barnier, the EU's chief Brexit negotiator, has said a permanent customs union — favoured by Labour — could be included in the Political Declaration. But although the issue was considered in the cross-party talks, the discussions foundered.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Read more: Political Declaration: the details

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: At the heart of the debate over Europe in the United Kingdom is the balance to be struck between two objectives: a desire for independence, sovereignty and autonomy against the need to retain access to European markets, which, the EU has always insisted, means adhering to EU rules.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Theresa May insisted the negotiated withdrawal deal was in the national interest and there was no viable alternative. She argued that it delivered on the referendum result: an end to free movement, an end to huge UK payments to the EU, and an exit from the unpopular EU structures on farming and fishing.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: However, the agreement brought hostility from both supporters and opponents of Brexit. In parliament, an alliance of forces resulted in the successive defeats for the government.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The main Labour opposition said the deal did not meet its six Brexit tests.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Derailed by the backstop

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The controversial backstop, the mechanism in the agreement to guarantee an open border on the island of Ireland, proved to be a major stumbling block. The difficulty is that the frontier between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland – one of the most politically sensitive borders in the world – will become an EU-UK land border after Brexit, yet the UK wishes to pursue an independent trade policy.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The backstop envisages the UK remaining in a "single customs territory" with the EU in the absence of a free trade deal, as a kind of insurance policy to keep the border open.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Eurosceptic critics suspect it will keep the UK strapped permanently to EU trade policy. EU sources pointed out that the UK-wide mechanism in the withdrawal agreement was included at the UK’s request, to avoid splitting off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), on whose support the government depends, has vehemently opposed any move they believe might separate Northern Ireland from the rest of the United Kingdom. Under the backstop, as set out in the deal, Northern Ireland would stay aligned to some EU rules.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: As the clock ticked down towards the original March 29 deadline, the UK and the EU said they had agreed a revised Brexit deal following weeks of deadlocked talks between London and Brussels. The British parliament had voted to seek “alternative arrangements” for the backstop after the first parliamentary defeat.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: EU27 leaders had refused to alter the text of the withdrawal agreement. But Theresa May said she had secured legally-binding changes over the backstop’s application. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said “meaningful legal assurances” had been given — while warning that there would be "no third chance" to revise the deal again.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: However, leading members of the Conservative anti-EU European Research Group (ERG) and the DUP rejected the new proposals, after consulting new legal opinion on the deal from the government's top lawyer. The deal suffered a second defeat on March 12.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The government decided the third vote in the House of Commons on March 29 would be only on the withdrawal deal, not on the declaration on future relations. This was partly to conform to a ruling by the Speaker who insisted on substantial changes from the previous vote. However, it still ended in defeat by 58 votes.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The parliamentary deadlock prompted moves by MPs from different parties to wrest control of the Brexit process and allow a series of "indicative votes" to explore alternative solutions to the government's deal. But there has been no majority for any particular solution, other than an opposition to no-deal.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The turmoil in the British domestic political scene has cut across party lines. Internal party divisions have affected both the UK government and opposition.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The ruling Conservative party has long been riven between Eurosceptic and Europhile factions. The main Labour opposition has seen tension between its largely pro-EU membership and a leadership more inclined to deliver Brexit. Both parties have been damaged by the issue.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: In early 2019, the Tories in particular haemorrhaged support to the new hardline Brexit Party. Meanwhile, both Conservatives and Labour suffered defections of some MPs to a new pro-EU centrist party — since renamed "The Independent Group for Change" — for reasons that included their leaders' stances on Brexit.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Tory turmoil boils over

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The defeated UK-EU exit deal represented a compromise. But the blurring of several of Theresa May's so-called "red lines" on the limits of EU power sparked fury within her divided Conservative Party. As negotiations with Brussels brought more UK concessions, a string of government resignations followed.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: After the 2017 general election, which left the Tories severely weakened in parliament, hostility amid their own ranks to any moves towards a "softer" Brexit restricted May's room for manoeuvre. Eurosceptics including the DUP strongly opposed her Brexit plan and the subsequent agreement, with many calling for the UK to leave the EU with no deal. They argue the accord ties the UK too closely to EU rules, compromising independence perhaps far into the future.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Equally, several pro-EU MPs also opposed a deal which, in their view, would leave the UK worse off than it had been inside the bloc. Some joined calls from opposition parties for a second referendum to see whether the country had changed its mind on Brexit.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Pressure from Tory Europhiles obliged the prime minister to open the door to a Brexit delay. Although she had long resisted calls from the Labour opposition for the UK to remain in a customs union with the EU, she suddenly changed tack on April 2 — only for cross-party talks to collapse weeks later.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Theresa May's fate was sealed after she revealed a fourth plan for getting her thrice-rejected Brexit deal through parliament. She tweaked the legislative package and crucially opened the door to a possible confirmatory referendum — a move which angered many in her party and sparked another government resignation.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The main opposition Labour Party has been criticised for an ambiguous Brexit policy, blamed for its poor performance at local and European elections in May.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Despite gradually moving towards backing a public vote to resolve the Brexit crisis, the leadership's reticence to back a second referendum has angered many among its large pro-EU membership.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: On July 28 leader Jeremy Corbyn said Labour would campaign for the UK to remain in the EU if Boris Johnson tried to implement a no-deal Brexit.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: He followed this up with a letter to MPs on August 14, vowing to hold a no-confidence vote in Johnson's government, which if passed would be followed by a temporary government under his leadership. Brexit would be delayed and a general election held — with Labour campaigning for a second referendum, with an option to remain in the EU.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Labour set out its position after the June 2016 referendum, saying it respected the result. It defined its priorities as securing a customs union with the EU and access to its markets, as well as ensuring the protection of standards over the environment, and consumer and workers' rights.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The party later moved to back a new EU referendum under certain conditions. Its National Executive Committee agreed on April 30, 2019, to support Labour's alternative plan for Brexit, and back a public vote if it couldn't secure changes to the government's deal or a general election.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The issue has caused internal divisions. Corbyn had resisted another referendum, and many MPs in Brexit-supporting constituencies are also hostile. But he has come under intense pressure from the party membership, and some prominent frontbench figures who favour another public vote.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Following Labour's election defeats in May, Corbyn said the "only way out" of the Brexit crisis was either a general election or a referendum on a deal. Deputy leader Tom Watson called for another referendum regardless, and for Labour to campaign for the UK to remain in the EU.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: On July 9 Labour tipped further in the direction of advocating a public vote — and backing EU membership. In a letter to party members, Corbyn called for a referendum on any Tory deal — or no deal — on Brexit, adding that Labour would campaign to remain in the EU. However, the letter did not spell out what Labour would do in power — bringing more accusations of ambiguity.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The pro-EU Liberal Democrats and the Independent Group for Change both oppose Brexit, and support a second referendum on the UK's EU membership. So do the Green Party, the Scottish National Party (SNP), and the Welsh party Plaid Cymru.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The Liberal Democrats have enjoyed a boost in opinion polls and performed well in the European elections. Newly-elected leader Jo Swinson, has vowed to do "whatever it takes to stop Brexit".

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The Brexit Party advocates leaving the EU on World Trade Organisation (WTO) terms, negotiating new terms afterwards — a position condemned as unrealistic and potentially disastrous by many mainstream politicians, economists and businesses. Leader Nigel Farage accuses the UK's political class of betraying the result of the 2016 referendum, adding that his new party's mission is to "change politics for good".

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The UK Independence Party (UKIP), which Farage once led and was obliterated at the European elections, also favours a no-deal Brexit and blocking a second referendum.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: The EU originally developed after World War Two, with the aim of promoting economic co-operation and trade between countries to stop them from going to war again. Its members' economies are now integrated around a single market allowing the free movement of goods, people, services and capital.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: Nineteen of the 28 member states use a single currency, the euro. The EU has its own institutions and passes laws affecting many issues across the union.

News_name: Brexit Guide: where are we now?
News_News_text_name: It highlights the benefits of membership as securing peace, promoting freedom and prosperity as part of the single market, safeguarding food and environmental standards, consumer benefits, protecting human rights, and enhancing Europe's global power.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: France is gearing up to host the Group of Seven (G7) nations for the international bloc’s annual summit.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: From August 24 to August 26, heads of state from seven of the world’s largest economies will descend on the seaside town of Biarritz towards the end of France’s vacation season.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: But what issues could be on the table for the G7 this year especially following US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the group's final communiqué last year?

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Euronews takes a look.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: The G7 is an informal group of seven nations that discusses economic and international issues at an annual summit.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: The group was created in 1975 as the Group of Six with Canada joining a year later so that advanced democracies could discuss economic policies. The European Union also became a member but does not hold the rotating presidency.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: The G7 was the Group of Eight (G8) between 1998 and 2014 when Russia was suspended for its annexation of Crimea which many states considered to be illegal.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: The presidency rotates amongst the seven members and the group typically issues a final statement or communiqué of agreed-upon initiatives.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: The G7 has often been viewed as a group of "rich nations".

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Economists expect that international economic issues such as technology, trade, and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will come up at this year’s G7 meeting. This would include the US/China and US/EU trade relationships as well as the succession of Christine Lagarde at the IMF.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Europe recently designated their IMF candidate as the Bulgarian and World Bank chief executive Kristalina Georgieva.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Economists also expect Facebook's new cryptocurrency Libra to be discussed after France announced plans to create a G7 cryptocurrency "task force" to investigate money laundering and consumer protection issues related to these new currencies.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: International taxation on digital companies could also be on the discussion table. France released a summary of the G7 finance ministers' July meeting stating that they had reached agreement on international taxation.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Trump later threatened to target French wine over France's tax on large technology companies.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: But some economists say the summit’s importance shouldn’t be “overemphasised”.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: “In practice, the G7 has been somewhat downgraded by the emergence of the G20 as the premier format for international economic policy coordination in late 2008,” said Nicolas Véron, an economist at the Peterson Institute for International Economics and senior fellow at Brussels-based think tank Bruegel.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: “For example, if you think of major issues of global economic governance like the role of the IMF and financial regulation and international finance in general, in the last ten years that has tended to be more of a matter of the G20 than the G7.”

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Nonetheless, this G7 summit should feature some interesting first meetings.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Trump and Boris Johnson will likely meet for the first time since Johnson became the UK’s new Prime Minister.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Last year’s G7 summit in Charlevoix, Canada ended with the US president disavowing the final communiqué.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: German Chancellor Angela Merkel shared what would become a memorable photograph taken at the summit in which leaders surrounded Trump in what appeared to be a tense exchange. Other photos of the same gathering showed leaders with a slightly more relaxed posture.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: But the US president left the G7 summit before the heads of state discussed climate change and German chancellor Angela Merkel called the aftermath “sobering and a bit depressing”.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: "I worked hard for a compromise, we struggled with it for a long time ... and then afterwards the withdrawal, so to speak, via tweet, is, of course, sobering and a bit depressing,” she said.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Trump broke from other leaders by calling for Russia to be readmitted into the G7. The year before, the G7 leaders noted that the U.S. was in the process of "reviewing its policies on climate change" and thus was unable to recommit to the Paris agreement.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: These disagreements are expected to come up at this year's meeting as well.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: “Everybody knows there’s a climate right now which is difficult with Trump’s designation of China as a currency manipulator and the trade situation...there is no meeting of minds presumably in the Group of Seven on most important issues of the day. So I'm not expecting anything big or particularly constructive from the meeting,” Véron said.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: France holds the presidency of the 2019 G7 and has picked the theme of "fighting inequality" for this year's summit. France is also including a number of other democracies and partners as part of the meeting.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: French President Emmanuel Macron talked about the theme at the UN General Assembly meeting last September.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: He said he wanted to include other powers because “the time when a club of rich countries could alone define the world’s balances is long gone”.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Those other countries will include “four major partners”: Australia, Chile, India and South Africa, and six African partners: Burkina Faso, Egypt, Senegal, and Rwanda.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: The summit comes during the height of the surfing and beach town’s tourist season, according to the Biarritz office of tourism.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: They expect the meeting to impact certain activities but are working to prepare merchants and shopkeepers for several days of disruption.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: There are two security zones. The one closest to the beach will have a heightened level of security.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: Residents and shop owners will have to present a badge to gain access to the area closest to the water which will be subject to heightened security.

News_name: What's the G7? A look at the economic summit coming to France
News_News_text_name: “It’s insane,” a local merchant told France 2’s evening newscast. “It would have been nice to do it in October or November. But during the height of the summer season… many [merchants] won’t survive the G7.”

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: With over 55,000 performances across 317 venues, the world’s largest arts festival, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is in full swing this month. While the Fringe is something Britain should be proud of, we must also recognise that a disproportionate number of the performers (and even the audience) will be white, middle class and wealthy. Although Britain’s creative industry is more inclusive than many parts of mainland Europe, there is still unmet potential.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: This matters because as long as the UK’s arts and media industry fail to reflect society, classism, racism and Islamophobia will continue to grow. This gap is being filled by grassroots producers and media outlets, but with a lack of access to opportunities, venues and funding, they are up against a well-oiled machine that has been conceived by and maintained for decades by Britain’s elite.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: The UK should see diversity in its arts industry as a strategic strength. At a time when its global economic and political clout is objectively in decline (many Fringe artists have demanded to be paid in dollars or euros citing Brexit uncertainty), cultural soft power will be an increasingly essential tool for its future engagement with a diverse Europe, and an even more diverse world.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: Britain’s cultural capital is drawn from more than just its flag and history. Media and art franchises - from James Bond and Harry Potter to the BBC itself - have come to define what the world associates with the UK. With almost half a million visitors each summer, The Edinburgh Fringe represents an incredible opportunity to reflect the rich cultural tapestry that makes Britain truly great. There is simply no other arts festival in Europe of a similar scale.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: However, what the Fringe boasts in size, it lacks in diversity. It was established in 1947 at a time when post-war Britain was unapologetically monocultural in its arts and media - and little has changed in the 72 years since. Last year, mixed-race actor Layton Williams received an official apology after he was kicked out of a venue in a case of racial profiling, and other performers of colour regularly describe feeling lonely and vulnerable amongst the overwhelmingly white audience and performers.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: In 2016, multi-award winning actor and rapper Riz Ahmed bemoaned the lack of opportunities in the UK arts industry for people of colour, going on to praise the US which, despite suffering greater racial prejudice and discrimination, regularly draws from a multicultural talent pool reflected across the sector, on stage and on screen.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: More often than not, bigotry and racism is born of ignorance of the Other. It is harder to discriminate against those whose stories we connect with and relate to. Working diligently in the cultural space alongside allies has been an essential part of how Jewish Americans, African Americans and even the LGBT community, have humanised the once hostile narratives that surrounded them.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: This same potential is present at the Fringe. Recent years have seen British Muslim Fringe performers like Tez Ilyas and Bilal Zafar launch promising careers that leverage authentic Muslim stories and tackle themes of racism and Islamophobia, but they are the exception that proves the rule.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: The vast majority of Fringe performers have a background of privilege that affords them access to this exclusive space. It can cost a comedian over €20,000 to take a show to the Fringe - ironic for a festival that was established with the idea of inclusion at its heart. These costs also extend

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: to the audience, which is often as well-off as many of the performers. For instance, a basic hotel room during the Fringe can cost several hundred euros per night.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: Indeed, the egalitarian spirit of the Fringe was quickly forgotten as the economics of the entertainment industry - and those privileged to run it - took control. It’s also no surprise that much of the most decorated talent in the UK arts and culture industry hail from the country’s most exclusive universities.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: If Britain wants to remain relevant in a world that is pushing cultures closer together than ever before, its stages and screens should tap the rich cultural diversity of our communities. When our art scene and media reflect all our citizens, we will also go a long way in tackling the racism and bigotry that festers in exclusionary spaces.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: Token representation is not enough. Change is needed at the top; from major broadcasters like the BBC to the organisers behind the Edinburgh Fringe. They needn't look far with grassroots outlets like British Muslim TV regularly platforming emerging talent and giving a voice to content creators that would otherwise be overlooked by the mainstream. It’s not just the Fringe that suffers as a result of its lack of representation, but rather the country as a whole.

News_name: The Edinburgh Fringe is white, middle class and elitist ǀ View
News_News_text_name: A diverse world needs diverse talent and as long as cultural spaces remain bastions for the white middle class, we will all suffer - whether we realise it or not.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: The heatwave that last week gripped Europe and smashed temperature records has now settled in Greenland... and the results are startling.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Read more: Europe heatwave: Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands topple all-time high temperature records

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: The second-largest ice sheet in the world is melting rapidly and the heatwave is exacerbating the process.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Greenland lost 160 billion tonnes of ice in July.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: While the thaw might seem distant geographically to many on the European mainland, its effects are far-reaching and consequential to every coastal resident in the world.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Greenland is already the biggest contributor to modern-day sea level rise and this melt in July alone had an impact equivalent to a 0.5mm rise in global sea levels.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: The thaw could break a record from July 2012, when 97% of the Greenland ice sheet experienced some degree of melting, because temperatures are expected to remain high, Ruth Mottram, a climatologist from the Danish meteorological service, told Euronews.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: The "defrosting season" lasts until the end of August and only "then we will know what the final figures for the season are," she added.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: The first measurements on the ground on August 1 showed 2019 melt was 1.2 times that of the previous record melt in 2012.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Scientists at the Norwegian centre expect 190 gigatonnes of ice to melt from the sheet by the end of the month — not quite the record levels reached in 2012.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: On Wednesday, the area that was exposed to temperatures above 0ºC and therefore considered to be melting consisted of 51% of the ice sheet — the highest percentage recorded this year.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: The thaw season in Greenland started a month earlier than normal in 2019, the second earliest date on record.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: This along with an episode of extreme thaw in June, followed by high temperatures in July, topped off with the current heatwave, contributed to the big thaw.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Temperature recordings were higher than normal at all weather stations in the country on Wednesday, said Mottram, but the "peak melt" is scheduled for Thursday.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: "High pressure associated with Europe's record heatwave has essentially shifted over Greenland," said climatologist Zack Labe.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: "This will cause temperatures to rise more than 10C above average on the entire Greenland ice sheet."

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Using the Copernicus European observation satellite network we can compare the thaw situation at the end of June in the same area in 2019 and the previous years.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Although it is not a scientific test, the differences are evident. Ice appears "flooded" in many areas.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Using the Copernicus European observation satellite network, we can compare the thaw at the end of June 2019 on the northeastern Greenland ice sheet to the same area in previous years.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: While rising sea levels are one effect of Greenland's ice sheet melting, the circulation of air mass is another problem.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Masses of fresh water poured into the sea remain on the surface because salt water is heavier.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: This alters air circulation currents and creates unusual weather patterns, which experts say favour extreme weather events, like the heatwaves in July.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: Heat also encourages evaporation, which causes heavier rainfall.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: With these consequences in mind, climate campaigners are calling for action in Greenland to limit the ice loss in Greenland.

News_name: How rapid ice melting in Greenland will affect us all
News_News_text_name: The Arctic as a whole is warming a rate that is twice as fast as the rest of the globe — a phenomenon that has been attributed to human-caused climate change.
